channel.title: Math Wikis on Ben's Math Site
channel.description: Recent content in Math Wikis on Ben's Math Site

item.description: Basis for a topological space Similar to the ideas behind bases in other areas of math. Definition Let $(X, \mathcal{T})$ be a topological space and let $\mathcal{B} \subset \mathcal{T}$. $\mathcal{B}$ is a basis for the topology $\mathcal{T}$ if and only if every open set is the union of elements of $\mathcal{B}$. If $\mathcal{B}$ is a basis, we call $B \in \mathcal{B}$ a basic open set. Properties Theorem 3.1: A set $\mathcal{B}$ is the basis for a given topology $\mathcal{T}$ on a set $X$ if and only if

Boundaries of sets Definition For a set $A$ in a topological space $(X, \mathcal{T})$, the boundary of $A$, denoted $\partial A$ or Bd$(A)$, is the intersection of the closures of $A$ and its complement, that is, the set $\partial A = \overline{X} \cap \overline{X - A}$. Properties Theorem 2.28: If $A$ is a set in a topological space $(X, \mathcal{T})$, the interior of $A$, the boundary of $A$, and the interior of the complement of $A$ are disjoint sets whose union is $X$.

Closed sets Definition In a topological space $(X, \mathcal{T})$, a closed set $A$ is a subset of $X$ that is equal to its closure ($\overline{A} = A$). That is, $A$ contains all its limit points. Properties of closed sets A set $A$ is closed if and only if its complement $X - A$ is open. This is Theorem 2.14 from my self-study work. If ${A_\alpha}_{\alpha \in \lambda}$ is a collection of closed sets, then $\bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha$ is closed, but $\bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha$ need not be closed.

Closures Taking a set and adding a few points to make it closed. Definition Let $(X, \mathcal{T})$ be a topological space with $A \subset X$. The closure of $A$ in $X$, denoted $\overline{A}$, Cl$(A)$, or Cl$_X(A)$ is the set $A$ together with all its limit points in $X$. Properties Theorem 2.13: The closure of a set is closed, that is, for a set $A$ in a topological space $(X, \mathcal{T})$, we have that $\overline{\overline{A}} = \overline{A}$.

Continuity Continuous functions can be drawn without picking up your pencil. The $\varepsilon$-$\delta$ definition, limit related definition A function $f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}$ is continuous at a point $c \in \mathcal{D}$ if and only if the limit of $f$ at $c$ exists and $\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)$. A function $f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}$ is **continuous** if and only if it is continuous at the point $c$ for all $c \in \mathcal{D}$.

Countable complement topology Basically what the name makes it sound like. It’s similar in definition to the finite complement topology. Definition Let $X$ be a set. A set $U$ is in the countable complement topology if and only if $X - U$ is countable or if $U = \emptyset$. This topology is also called the cocountable topology. Properties Countable sets are closed in this topology. #topology

DeMorgan’s Laws DeMorgan’s Laws relate complements of unions and intersections. Statement Let $X$ be a set and let ${A_\alpha}_{\alpha \in \lambda}$ be a collection of subsets of $X$. Then $$X - \left( \bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha \right) = \bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} (X - A_\alpha)$$ and $$X - \left( \bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha \right) = \bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} (X - A_\alpha).$$ Proof for a finite collection The following is a proof of a less general version of DeMorgan’s Laws using a finite collection of sets instead of the collection ${A_\alpha}_{\alpha \in \lambda}$.

Discontinuities Definition A function $f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}$ is discontinuous at a point $c \in \mathcal{D}$ if and only if $f$ is not continuous at $c$. That is, if the limit $\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x)$ does not exist or is not equal to $f(c)$. Types of discontinuities Let $f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}$ be a function and $c \in \mathcal{D}$. Then $f$ has an infinite discontinuity at $c$ if and only if $\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = \pm \infty$.

The discrete topology The discrete topology is the finest topology on a given set. A set together with the discrete topology is called a discrete space. Definition Let $X$ be a set. Then the discrete topology on $X$ contains all subsets of $X$, that is, the topology is $\mathcal{T} = 2^X$, the power set of $X$. Properties If $(X, \mathcal{T})$ is a topological space, then it is a discrete space if and only if all singletons are open.

The Double Headed Snake The body is the positive real line and the two heads are the points $0'$ and $0''$. Definition The Double Headed Snake is the topological space on the set $\mathbb{R}_{+00}$ of all positive real numbers together with the numbers $0'$ and $0''$ that is generated by the basis $\mathcal{B}$ containing sets of the form $(a,b)$, $(0,b) \cup {0'}$, and $(0,b) \cup {0''}$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$.

Fineness and Coarseness Given two topologies on a set $X$, we can compare them with the notions of fineness and coarseness. You can think about the fineness of a topology determining the amount you can see (you “see” the open sets) when looking at the set $X$. If a topology is very fine, you can see a lot of open sets, but if the topology is very coarse, things are “blurry” because there are few open sets.

Finite complement topology Basically what the name makes it sound like. Similar in definition to the countable complement topology. Definition Let $X$ be a set. A set $U$ is in the finite complement topology if and only if $X - U$ is finite or if $U = \emptyset$. This topology is also called the cofinite topology. Properties Finite sets are closed in the finite complement topology. #topology

Functions Definitions A function $f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C}$ is a set of ordered pairs $(a,b)$ where $a \in \mathcal{D}$ and $b \in \mathcal{C}$ with the property that if $(a,b) \in f$ and $(a,c) \in f$, then $b=c$. We call the set $\mathcal{D}$ the domain of $f$ and the set $\mathcal{C}$ the codomain of $f$. Notation If $(a,b) \in f$, we write $f(a)=b$. Examples Polynomial functions are those of the form $$p(x) = \sum_{k=0}^n a_k x^k.

Indiscrete topology The coarsest possible topology on a set $X$. Definition Let $X$ be a set. The indiscrete topology is $\mathcal{T} = {\emptyset, X}$. The topological space $(X, {\emptyset, X})$ is called an indiscrete space. Properties By definition, the only sets in the indiscrete topology that are open are $X$ and $\emptyset$, and these are also the only closed sets. #topology

Infimum and supremum Definitions Let $A \subset \mathbb{R}$. We say $c \in \mathbb{R}$ is an upper bound of $A$ if and only if $c \geq a$ for all $a \in A$. We say $c \in \mathbb{R}$ is a lower bound of $A$ if and only if $c \leq a$ for all $a \in A$. We say $c \in \mathbb{R}$ is the greatest/largest/maximum element of $A$ if and only if $c$ is an upper bound of $A$ and $c \in A$.

Interior of a set Points in the set and not on the boundary. Definition Let $(X, \mathcal{T})$ be a topological space and let $A$ be a subset of $X$. The interior of $A$, denoted $A^\circ$ or Int$(A)$, is the largest open set contained entirely within $A$, that is, the set $$A^\circ = \bigcup_{U \subset A, , U \in \mathcal{T}} U.$$ Properties Theorem 2.26: A point $p$ is an interior point of a set $A$ in a topological space $(X, \mathcal{T})$ if and only if there exists an open set $U$ with $p \in U \subset A$.

Isolated points Definition Let $(X,\mathcal{T})$ be a topological space, $A$ a subset of $X$, and $p \in A$ a point. We say $p$ is an isolated point if it is not a limit point of $A$. Properties If $p$ is an isolated point of a set $A$ in a topological space $(X, \mathcal{T})$, then there exists an open set $U$ such that $U \cap A = {p}$. Examples In the topological space defined by $X = {a,b,c,d}$ and $\mathcal{T} = {\emptyset, X, {a},{a,b}}$, the point $b$ is in the set $A = {b,c}$, but is not a limit point of $A$ since ${a,b}$ is open but $({a,b} - {b}) \cap A = \emptyset$.

Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT) Theorem statement Let $f: [a,b] \to \mathbb{R}$ be continuous and let $L \in \mathbb{R}$ be a number strictly between $f(a)$ and $f(b)$. Then there exists a $c \in (a,b)$ such that $f(c) = L$. Lemma Let $a, L \in \mathbb{R}$ and let $f$ be a function that is continuous at $a$ with $f(a) < L$ ($f(a) > L$). Then there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that $) < L$ ($f(x) > L$).

K-topology Denoted $\mathbb{R}_{\text{har}}$ in the textbook I’ve been using, the K-topology is a topology on $\mathbb{R}$. Definition Let $K = {1/n}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ be the harmonic sequence. The K-topology on $\mathbb{R}$ is generated by the basis containing sets of the form $(a,b)$ and sets of the form $(a,b) - K$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$ with $a < b$. Properties $\mathbb{R}_{\text{har}}$ is finer than the standard topology. Separation properties $T_1$-space Hausdorff #topology

Limit points Generalizing more things from calculus – this time the idea of a point being “arbitrarily close” to a set. Definition Let $(X, \mathcal{T})$ be a topological space, let $A \subset X$ be a subset, and let $p \in X$ be a point. We say that $p$ is a limit point of $A$ if and only if for each open set $U$ containing $p$, $(U - {p}) \cap A \neq \emptyset$.

Limits Intuitively, “$\lim \limits_{x \to a} f(x) = L$” means that the outputs of a function $f$ approaches the value $L$ as the inputs approach the value $a$. The $\varepsilon$-$\delta$ definition of a limit (and variants) Let $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ be a function and let $a,L \in \mathbb{R}$. $\lim \limits_{x \to a} f(x) = L$ if and only if for every $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that $0 < ) - L) = L$ if and only if for every $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists an $N \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $x > N$ implies that $) - L) = \infty$ if and only if for every $N \in N$, there exists a $\delta > 0$ such that $0 < ) > N$.

The Sorgenfrey Line It’s like $\mathbb{R}$ but finer and… worse. It’s a topological space also known as the lower limit topology on $\mathbb{R}$, sometimes denoted $\mathbb{R}{\text{LL}}$ or $\mathbb{R}{\text{bad}}^1$. $\R$ Definition The Sorgenfrey Line is the topological space on $\mathbb{R}$ generated by the basis of sets of the form $[a, b) = {x \in \mathbb{R} \mid a \leq x < b}$ for $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$. Properties Separation properties $T_1$-space Hausdorff Regular and a $T_3$-space Normal and a $T_4$-space #topology

The Moore plane Also called the Upper Half-Plane with the Sticky Bubble Topology and denoted $\mathbb{H}_{\text{bub}}$ in the textbook I’ve been using. Definition Let $\mathbb{H} = {(x,y) \mid x,y \in \mathbb{R}, y \geq 0}$. The Moore plane is this set with the topology generated by the basis containing all balls of the form $B((x,y), r)$ where $0<r \leq y$, and all balls of the form $B((x,y),r) \cup {(x,0)}$ where $r = y > 0$.

Open sets Definition In a topological space $(X, \mathcal{T})$, an open set $U$ is a set with $U \in \mathcal{T}$. Properties of open sets A set $U$ is open if and only if for each point $p \in U$, there exists an open set $U_p$ such that $p \in U_p \subset U$. This is Theorem 2.3 in: Theorem 2.3 from my self-study work. If ${U_\alpha}_{\alpha \in \lambda}$ is a collection of open sets, then $\bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha$ is open, but $\bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha$ need not be open.

Sequences An infinite list of things. Definitions For real numbers, a sequence is a function $f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}$, where the image of the number $n$ under $f$ is typically called $a_n$. The sequence is written by listing its images: $a_1, a_2, \dots$ or for short, ${a_n}$. In a topological space $(X, \mathcal{T})$, a sequence is a function $f: \mathbb{N} \to X$, where the image of the number $i$ under $f$ is typically called $x_i$.

The standard topology The standard topology is a topology defined on $\mathbb{R}^n$ for $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Definitions The Euclidean distance between two points $x = (x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n)$ and $y = (y_1, y_2, \dots, y_n)$ is defined as $$d(x,y) = \left( \sum_{i = 1}^n (x_i - y_i)^2 \right)^{\frac{1}{2}}.$$ An open ball of radius $\varepsilon > 0$ around a point $p \in \mathbb{R}^n$ is the set $B(p, \varepsilon) = {x \mid d(p,x) < \varepsilon}$.
My Topology self-study work I’ve been using the book Topology Through Inquiry and proofs and exercises I’ve done from the book can be found here: Math #topology

The topologist’s sine curve A set in the standard topology on $\mathbb{R}^2$. Definition In $(\mathbb{R}^2, \mathcal{T}_\text{std})$, the topologist’s sine curve is the set $$S = \left{ \left( x, \sin \left(\frac{1}{x}\right) \right) , \bigg ) \right}.$$ Properties Every point in the set ${(0,y) \mid -1 \leq y \leq 1 }$ is a limit point of the topologist’s sine curve. Since none of the above points are in $S$, $S$ is not closed.

What does it mean to be a topology? A topology on a set is a way of determining which subsets are open, closed, neither, or both. Elements of open sets can be thought of as being “close” in a way that isn’t dependent on notions of distance. If $X$ is a set and $\mathcal{T}$ is a topology on $X$, then we call $(X, \mathcal{T})$ a topological space. Definition Let $X$ be a set.

Arithmetic progression topology Definition The arithmetic progression topology is a topology on $\mathbb{Z}$ generated by the basis of sets of arithmetic progressions (sets of the form ${az + b \mid z \in \mathbb{Z}}$ for $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$, $a \neq 0$) and is denoted $\mathbb{Z}_\text{arith}$. #topology
#calculus
Hausdorff spaces This content is coming soon. #topology
